moves.1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf: Gligorich and I have a standing feud with this position, which we've reached no less than three times.
moves.11. Bxf6: Interesting is 11 B-N2 B-N2 12 KR-K1 P-N4 13 N-Q5?! PxN 14 PxP K-B1 15 N-B5 R-B1, and Black won (Bernstein-Fischer, 1957-8 US Championship.)
moves.11... gxf6 12. f5: Giving up the K5 square in order to exert pressure on K6.
moves.12... Ne5: Vladimir Simagin gave this move a "?" and proceeded to analyze the alternative 12... P-N5 13 PxP PxN 14 PxN ch BxP 15 P-K5, etc. By this logic the whole variation is unsound for Black.
moves.13. Qh3 O-O: Tigran Petrosian and Mikhail Tal happened to stroll by the board at this instant. Petrosian made a wry face which looked to me like "Can Black do this and live?" But if Black tries 13... B-Q2, on 14 P-N5! PxNP 15 PxP PxP 16 NxP Black's game collapses.
moves.14. Nce2: Intending N-B4, pressuring the Black KP.
moves.14... Kh8 15. Nf4 Rg8 16. Rg1: Gligorich gives 16 B-K2 as correct: after 16... Q-N2 17 PxP PxP it's anybody's game.
moves.16... d5: More prudent is 16... Q-N2 (17 R-K1 Q-N3!)
moves.17. fxe6 dxe4 18. Nd5 Qc5: Black's game hangs by a hair.
moves.19. Nxe7: If White tries 19 N-B5! the key line is 19... QxR 20 N/B5xB BxP 21 NxR BxP 22 Q-R6 BxR 23 N/N8xP Q-KN3 24 QxQ PxQ 25 KxB with winning chances.
moves.19... Qxe7 20. Nf5 Qxe6 21. Qh6 Bd7: Defending against the powerful threat of R-Q8.
moves.22... Nxg4 23. Rxg4: Forced (23 RxQ? NxQ winning a piece.)
moves.23... Qxf5 24. Rxg8+: Handing Black the game on a platter (24... KxR RxBP Q-K4, with Black a Pawn ahead with a dominating position.)
moves.24... Rxg8: Black hands it right back, missing the win.
moves.25. Rxf6 Qd5 26. Rd6 Qf5 27. Rf6 Qg5+: I should have contented myself with a draw by repetition (27... Q-Q4 28 R-Q6, etc.)
moves.32... Re1+ 33. Kf4 Bd1: Nowadays I would know better than to try and squeeze a win out of such a simplified ending.
moves.34. Ke5: Gligorich invites me to overextend myself.
moves.34... e3 35. Bf5 Rg1 36. Rxh7+ Kg8 37. R: Black should simply force a draw with 37... P-K7 38 K-B6 K-R1 39 R-R7 ch K-N1 40 R-QB7 K-R1, etc.
moves.38. Bxg4 Rxg4 39. Rc3 e2 40. Re3 Rg2: Black can still hold the draw.
moves.41. Kd4 e1=Q: if 41... RxRP? 42 K-Q3, Black is lost.
moves.42. Rxe1 Rxc2 43. Rb1 Kf7: Avoiding 43... RxRP? 44 K-B5 with a fatal penetration on the Q side.
moves.45... Rxh2 46. Kc5 Kd7 47. Kb6 Ra2 48. K: 49 KxP K-B2 leads to a book draw.
moves.49... Kd6 50. Kb6 Kd7 51. b4 Rh3 52. Rc1: After the game, Fridrik Olafsson scolded me: "How can you play an ending like this so fast?" (I'd only been taking a few seconds per move for the last dozen moves or so.) "Because there's no danger. It's a dead draw," I replied.  Had I known then what I know now, I would have selected 52... R-R4, and if 53 R-B5 RxR 54 KxR K-B2 55 KxP K-N2 holding the opposition with a book draw.
moves.53. Kxb5: Now it's Gligorich's turn to err. As Olafsson showed me, White can win with 53 R-B7 ch! It's hard to believe. I stayed up all night analyzing, finally convincing myself and, incidentally, learning a lot about Rook and Pawn endings in the process. Black cannot get his King in front of the Pawn (53 R-B7 ch K-Q3 54 R-B6 ch K-Q2 55 KxP R-N1 ch 56 R-N6 R-KR8 57 R-N7 ch K-B1 58 K-R6 R-R3 ch 59 K-R7 with a book win.)
moves.53... Rb8+ 54. Ka4 Ra8+: The game was adjourned again, but the crisis has passed.
moves.55. Kb3 Rc8 56. Rxc8 Kxc8 57. Kc4 Kb8: Draw agreed. Black has the distant opposition.
